Ini Tiga Tuntutan Petani Tembakau yang Demo di Kantor Sri Mulyani
04 Nov 2019, 05:57 by Vadhia Lidyana


Foto: Demo Petani Tembakau di Depan Kementerian Keuangan, (Vadhia Lidyana/detikFinance)

Jakarta - Asosiasi Petani Tembakau Indonesia (APTI) Jawa Barat (Jabar) sejak pagi hingga siang ini melakukan unjuk rasa di depan kantor Menteri Keuangan Sri Mulyani Indrawati. Sekitar 400 orang petani tembakau itu menyampaikan protesnya terhadap tiga kebijakan pemerintah yang berkaitan dengan hasil tembakau.Pertama, APTI Jabar mengajukan keberatan atas kenaikan cukai rokok sekitar 23% yang diatur dalam Peraturan Menteri Keuangan (PMK) nomor 152 tahun 2019."Yang pertama memperhatikan kenaikan cukai, ini perlu dipertimbangkan, jangan terlalu tinggi sampai 23%. Kami minta 10-15%. Kata Pak Dirjen itu di dalam proses pembahasan di tingkat menteri," ujar Pengurus DPC APTI Jabar, Didi Rohmana kepada detikcom di kantor Kemenkeu, Jakarta, Senin (4/11/2019).Kedua, terkait Dana Bagi Hasil (DBH) Cukai Hasil Tembakau (CHT) yang diatur dalam PMK nomor 222 tahun 2017. Dalam aturan tersebut, Didi mengatakan, petani meminta agar DBH CHT yang diperuntukkan untuk petani dan juga untuk program kesehatan di Pemerintah Daerah (Pemda) dibagi rata, yakni 50% dan 50%. Didi mengungkapkan, dalam regulasi tersebut diatur DBH CHT untuk kesehatan minimal 50%. Dalam implementasinya, DBH CHT untuk kesehatan dapat tembus hingga 90%, dan untuk petaninya hanya 10%."DBH CHT kan dibagi dua, untuk kesehatan dan untuk petani. Pembagian PMK yang sekarang itu kan paling sedikit 50% untuk kesehatan. Jadikan 50-50% lah, jadi ada untuk petani. Tapi kalau paling sedikit itu petani kan hanya 10%. Makanya kami minta pembatasannya jangan minimal, tapi maksimal," terang Didi.
Ketiga, terkait volume impor hasil tembakau di industri. APTI meminta agar pemerintah membatasi impor tembakau agar tembakau petani dalam negeri bisa terserap lebih banyak dan harga tak anjlok."Impor tembakau yang besar-besaran masuk ke kita, makanya harga tembakau kita turun karena dilanda impor. Itu kebanyakan di Jawa Tengah (Jateng), di pabrik-pabrik rokok. Kalau impor terlalu banyak otomatis harga tembakau lokal akan turun," papar Didi.Dalam aksi tersebut, 12 orang perwakilan APTI Jabar menemui Direktur Jenderal Bea dan Cukai Kemenkeu, Heru Pambudi untuk menyampaikan tiga poin di atas. Pertemuan itu berlangsung hampir dua jam.

These are the Three Demands of Tobacco Farmers who Demonstrated at the Sri Mulyani Office
04 Nov 2019, 05:57 by Vadhia Lidyana


Photo: Tobacco Farmers Demo in Front of the Ministry of Finance, (Vadhia Lidyana / detikFinance)

Jakarta - The Indonesian Tobacco Farmers Association (APTI) West Java (West Java) has been holding a demonstration in the morning in front of the office of the Minister of Finance Sri Mulyani Indrawati. About 400 tobacco farmers expressed their protest against the three government policies related to tobacco products. First, APTI Jabar raised an objection to the cigarette excise tax increase of about 23% as stipulated in Minister of Finance Regulation (PMK) number 152 2019. "The first to pay attention to the increase excise, this needs to be considered, not too high up to 23%. We ask for 10-15%. The Director General said in the process of discussion at the ministerial level, "said DTI APTI Jabar Executive Board, Didi Rohmana told AFP at the Ministry of Finance office, Jakarta, Monday (4/11/2019). Second, related to Revenue Sharing Funds (DBH) for Tobacco Product Excise (CHT) regulated in PMK number 222 of 2017. In the regulation, Didi said, farmers asked that the CHT DBH be intended for farmers and also for health programs in the Regional Government (Pemda) divided equally, ie 50% and 50%. Didi revealed, the regulation stipulates a minimum of 50% of DBH CHT for health. In its implementation, DBH CHT for health can penetrate up to 90%, and for farmers only 10%. "DBH CHT is divided into two, for health and for farmers. The current distribution of PMK is at least 50% for health. "There is% for farmers. But if at least the farmers are only 10%. Therefore, we ask that the restrictions should not be minimal, but maximum," explained Didi.
Third, related to the volume of imports of tobacco products in the industry. APTI requests that the government restrict tobacco imports so that domestic farmers' tobacco can be absorbed more and prices do not plummet. "Large-scale tobacco imports come to us, so the price of our tobacco falls because it is hit by imports. That's mostly in Central Java (Central Java), in cigarette factories. If imports are too much, the price of local tobacco will automatically go down, "said Didi. In the action, 12 representatives of the West Java APTI met with the Director General of Customs and Excise of the Ministry of Finance, Heru Pambudi to convey the three points above. The meeting lasted almost two hours.
